The '''Spanish 1977 Amnesty Law''' is a law promulgated by the [[Parliament of Spain]] in 1977, two years after [[caudillo]] [[Francisco Franco]]'s death.<ref name="Ackar2010">Ackar, Kadribasic (2010) [https://books.google.com/books?id=_hp7nOXOBuIC&pg=PA132 Transitional Justice in Democratization Processes: The Case of Spain from an International Point of View], ''International Journal of Rule of Law, Transitional Justice and Human Rights'', pp. 132-33.</ref> The law freed [[political prisoners]] and permitted those exiled to return to Spain, but guaranteed impunity for those who participated in crimes<ref>Miriam M. Basilio, ''Visual Propaganda, Exhibitions, and the Spanish Civil War'' (Ashgate, 2013), p. 220.</ref> under the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] and [[Francoist Spain]].<ref name="Ackar2010"/> The law is still in force, and has been used as a reason for not investigating and prosecuting Francoist [[Human rights in Spain|human rights violations]].<ref name="Aguilar">Paloma Aguilar, "The Timing and the Scope of Reparation, Truth and Justice Measures: A Comparison of the Spanish, Argentinian and Chilean Cases" in [https://books.google.com/books?id=0Z3qPlIAvD0C&pg=PA505 ''Building a Future on Peace and Justice: Studies on Transitional Justice''] (eds. [[Kai Ambos]], Judith Large, and Marieke Wierda: Springer, 2009), pp. 505, 521-2.</ref>
The act institutionalized Spain's "[[pact of forgetting]]"—a decision among Spanish parties and political actors, during and after the [[Spanish transition to democracy]], not to address atrocities committed by the [[Spanish State]].<ref>Omar G. Encarnación, ''Spanish Politics: Democracy After Dictatorship'' (Polity, 2008), p. 133.</ref><ref>Ofelia Ferrán & Lisa Hilbink, "Introduction: Legalities of Violence in Contemporary Spain" in ''Legacies of Violence in Contemporary Spain: Exhuming the Past, Understanding the Present'' (Routledge, 2016), p. 2.</ref> The 1977 amnesty has been criticized by scholars for equating "victims and victimizers" and for shielding human rights violators from prosecution and punishment.<ref name="Ackar2010"/> Spain has argued that perpetrators of crimes against humanity cannot be prosecuted for crimes committed before 1939, but the UN takes the view that Francoist crimes should be investigated.<ref name="Publico10Feb2012">[http://www.publico.es/espana/421451/la-onu-da-la-razon-a-garzon-y-pide-investigar-el-franquismo/comentarios-valorados ''La ONU da la razón a Garzón y pide investigar el franquismo''], ''[[Público (Spain)|Público]]'' (Publico.es), 10/02/2012</ref> In February 2012 the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] demanded the 1977 Amnesty Law to be repealed on the basis that it violates [[international human rights law]]. The Commissioner referred to Spain's obligation to comply with the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]]. Under international human rights law, there is no [[statute of limitations]] for [[crimes against humanity]].<ref name="Reuters2012">[http://news.trust.org//item/?map=spain-must-lift-amnesty-for-franco-era-crimes-un Spain must lift amnesty for Franco era crimes-U.N.], Reuters (February 10, 2012).</ref> In 2013, a UN working group of experts called upon Spain to repeal the 1977 law.<ref name="Reuters2013">[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-franco/u-n-tells-spain-to-revoke-franco-era-amnesty-law-idUSBRE98T0YJ20130930 U.N. tells Spain to revoke Franco-era amnesty law], Reuters (September 30, 2013).</ref>
In 2008, Judge [[Baltasar Garzón]] briefly began an official inquiry, symbolically indicting Franco for the disappearance of more than 100,000 people. In 2009, [[Manos Limpias]], a far-right syndicate, brought criminal charges against the judge for defying the amnesty law.<ref name="Reuters2013"/><ref>Editorial, [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/05/opinion/sunday/truth-on-trial-in-spain.html Truth on Trial in Spain], ''New York Times'' (February 5, 2012).</ref> Garzón was acquitted of the charges of "knowingly acting without jurisdiction" relating to his investigation of Francoist crimes, but was disbarred for 11 years by the [[Spanish Supreme Court]] in 2012 on an unrelated charge.<ref>[[Sarah Leggott]], ''Memory, War, and Dictatorship in Recent Spanish Fiction by Women'' (Bucknell University Press, 2015), p. 20.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1977 in Spain]] [[Category:1977 in law]] [[Category:Amnesty laws]] [[Category:Crimes against humanity]] [[Category:Francoist Spain]] [[Category:Spanish law]] [[Category:Spanish transition to democracy]]

[[File:Vladislav Surkov 7 May 2013.jpeg|thumb|Vladislav Surkov]] In October 2016, [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] hacker group CyberHunta [[Internet leak|leaked]] over a gigabyte of emails and other documents alleged to belong to Russian political operative and senior [[Kremlin]] official [[Vladislav Surkov]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Windrem|first1=Robert|title=Payback? Russia gets hacked, revealing top Putin aide's secrets|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/ukraine-crisis/payback-russia-gets-hacked-revealing-putin-aide-s-secrets-n673956|work=NBC News|date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Known as Russia's "[[Éminence grise|grey cardinal]]", Surkov serves as a political adviser to President [[Vladimir Putin]] and is the architect of Russia's ideology of [[sovereign democracy]].
The document leak included over 2,300 emails from Surkov's inbox.<ref name="DFRL"/> The emails illustrate Russian plans to politically destabilize Ukraine and the coordination of affairs with major opposition leaders in [[Separatist forces of the war in Donbass|separatist]] east Ukraine.<ref name="IBTUK"/> The release included a document sent to Surkov by [[Denis Pushilin]], former Chair of the [[People's Soviet of the Donetsk People's Republic|People's Soviet]] of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]], listing casualties that occurred during 2014.<ref name="DFRL"/> It also included a 22-page outline of "a plan to support nationalist and separatist politicians and to encourage early parliamentary elections in Ukraine, all with the aim of undermining the government in Kiev."<ref name="FP"/>
The Kremlin has said that the leaked documents are fake.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Shaun|title=Kremlin puppet master's leaked emails are price of return to political frontline|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/26/kremlin-puppet-masters-leaked-emails-vladislav-surkov-east-ukraine|work=The Guardian|date=26 October 2016}}</ref>
==Authenticity== Washington think tank [[Atlantic Council]]'s Digital Forensic Research Lab conducted an analysis of the emails. They determined that they were genuine, based partially on the routing information.<ref name="NYT1">{{cite news|last1=Kramer|first1=Andrew E.|title=Ukrainian Hackers Release Emails Tying Top Russian Official to Uprising|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/28/world/europe/ukraine-russia-emails.html?smid=tw-nytimesworld&smtyp=cur|work=The New York Times|date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Russian entrepreneur [[Yevgeny Chichvarkin]] confirmed that his emails from the document dump were authentic, saying "Yes, this is my original text."<ref name="NYT1"/> Russian journalist Svetlana Babaeva also verified that her three emails from the leak were genuine.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Amos|first1=Howard|title=Hackers: emails show ties between Kremlin, Ukraine rebels|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_RUSSIA_UKRAINE_HACKING?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|work=Associated Press|date=26 October 2016}}</ref>
Kremlin press secretary [[Dmitry Peskov]] suggested that the emails did not belong to Surkov, saying that he "does not use email."<ref name="Newsweek">{{cite news|last1=Sharkov|first1=Damien|title=Kremlin denies Putin aide's email was hacked—'he does not use email'|url=http://www.newsweek.com/kremlin-denies-putin-aide-hack-because-he-does-not-use-email-514038?rx=us|work=Newsweek|date=27 October 2016|quote='I familiarized myself (with the leak),' he said. 'A curious document. I can say that it is not him.'}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Песков опроверг сообщения о взломе почты Суркова|url=http://www.interfax.ru/russia/534205|work=Interfax|date=26 October 2016|language=ru-RU}}</ref> Oleksandr Tkachuk of [[Security Service of Ukraine]] stated that they had managed to "authenticate a number of documents in the release" but could not confirm the authenticity of the entire batch of documents.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schreck|first1=Carl|title=Kremlin Brushes Off E-Mail Leak Allegedly Showing Russian Hand In Ukraine Conflict|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-surkov-leaked-emails-authentic/28076329.html|work=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|date=26 October 2016}}</ref>
==Publication== On 23 October 2016, Ukrainian hacker group CyberHunta published correspondence that it alleged was from Surkov's office email account.<ref>{{cite web|title=КИБЕРХУНТА ПЕРЕДАЕТ ПРИВЕТ СУРКОВУ|url=http://cyberhunta.com/news/kiberhunta-peredaet-privet-surkovu/|publisher=Cyberhunta.com|language=Russian|date=23 October 2016}}</ref> Volunteers from the open-source intelligence initiative [[Inform Napalm]] requested additional evidence from an alliance of hacker groups that includes CyberHunta, RUH8, FalconsFlame, and TRINITY. They secured the release of a 1GB Microsoft Outlook data file. Inform Napalm reported that the hackers also were in possession of documents from 2015 and 2016 that were being analysed by intelligence agencies and were not released due to their operational value.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bjorn|first1=Falcon|title=SurkovLeaks: 1GB mail cache retrieved by Ukrainian hacktivists (English)|url=https://informnapalm.org/en/surkovleaks/|publisher=Inform Napalm|language=English|date=25 October 2016}}</ref>
New batches of emails from the leak were further published in November 2017<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stopfake.org/oskolki-russkogo-mira/|title=Осколки «Русского мира»|date=2017-11-13|work=StopFake.org|access-date=2017-11-13|language=ru-RU}}</ref> and April 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/leaked-emails-expose-russian-dirty-tricks-cmfkskj82|title=Leaked emails expose Russian dirty tricks|last=Fisher|first=Lucy|date=2018-04-02|work=The Times|access-date=2018-04-02|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Haynes|first2=Deborah|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}</ref>
==Contents== The document leak was a [[Microsoft Outlook]] data file (.PST) that included 2,337 emails from the inbox of Surkov's prm_surkova@gov.ru. The released material covers a period from September 2013 to November 2014. The email address appears to have been an office account run by Surkov's aides, including "Masha" and "Yevgenia".<ref name="DFRL">{{cite web|author1=Digital Forensic Research Lab|title=Breaking Down the Surkov Leaks – DFRLab|url=https://medium.com/dfrlab/breaking-down-the-surkov-leaks-b2feec1423cb#.t4wz7vsnx|website=Medium|publisher=Atlantic Council|date=25 October 2016}}</ref> Among the documents were scans of Surkov's and his family's [[passport]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gallagher|first1=Sean|title=Some hacked e-mails, documents from Putin advisor confirmed as genuine|url=https://arstechnica.com/security/2016/10/some-hacked-e-mails-documents-from-putin-advisor-confirmed-as-genuine/|work=Ars Technica|date=27 October 2016}}</ref> While the vast majority of the emails comprise routine briefings and schedules, a small handful are of geopolitical significance or potentially incriminating.<ref name="DFRL"/> These emails illustrate Russian plans to politically destabilize Ukraine and the coordination of affairs with major opposition leaders in separatist east Ukraine.<ref name="IBTUK">{{cite news|last1=Murdock|first1=Jason|title=Surkov leaks: Thousands of hacked emails reportedly from high-ranking Kremlin official published|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/surkov-leaks-thousands-hacked-emails-high-ranking-kremlin-officials-published-1588645|work=International Business Times UK|date=27 October 2016}}</ref>
An email sent to Surkov and others on 14 June 2014 by [[Denis Pushilin]], the former Chair of the [[People's Soviet of the Donetsk People's Republic|People's Soviet]] of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]], contains a document listing casualties that occurred from 26 May to 6 June 2014.<ref name="DFRL"/> The list of casualties includes a row for an unnamed soldier listed as "VDV Pskovsky" ("ВДВ Псковский"), a designation for a deployment of [[Russian Airborne Troops]] (VDV) from the city of [[Pskov]].<ref name="Newsweek"/> Paratroopers based in Pskov were thought to be among the first of Russia's covert casualties in Ukraine in 2014. The Pskov-based [[76th Guards Air Assault Division]] was awarded the [[Order of Suvorov]] by Putin for unspecified tasks in August 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russian reporters 'attacked at secret soldier burials'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28949582|work=BBC News|date=27 August 2014}}</ref>
An email sent to Surkov from a Russian government account on 18 June 2014 detailed the practicalities of Russia absorbing a portion of Ukraine. An email attachment included a briefing paper titled "On the Risks of an Economic Blockade of the LNR and DNR". The paper noted that 30% of the [[Donbass]] electrical supply comes from power plants in [[Zaporizhzhya]]. The document includes suggestions to supplement electrical supply in Donbass with power from the [[Rostov Nuclear Power Plant]] in Russia. The document's author also suggested increasing iron ore shipments and connecting Donbass to the [[Voronezh Oblast]] electricity grid.<ref>{{cite news|last1=MacDonald|first1=Euan|title=Surkov briefed on countering Ukrainian blockade of ‘separatist republics’ |url=https://www.kyivpost.com/russia/surkov-briefed-countering-ukrainian-economic-blockade-separatist-republics.html|work=KyivPost|date=28 October 2016}}</ref>
One of the emails to Surkov from [[Konstantin Malofeev]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Ukrainian hackers leak emails that show ties between Kremlin, rebels {{!}} Toronto Star|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2016/10/26/ukrainian-hackers-leak-emails-that-show-ties-between-kremlin-rebels.html|work=Toronto Star|agency=Associated Press|date=26 October 2016}}</ref> contained a list of recommended candidates for positions in the separatist government prior to their appointments.<ref name="NYT1"/>
The documents also included a spreadsheet containing the budget for a newspaper in [[Donetsk]].<ref name="NYT1"/>
On 25 August 2014, a Russian official forwarded an email to Surkov from ''Russian Reporter'' editor Vitaly Leybin. The email bore the title "corrections in the text" and concerned a letter to the Ukrainian government from the "public representatives of the Donbass." A nearly identical article, purportedly from citizens living in Ukraine, appeared in ''Russian Reporter'' days later with only minor changes. Within the week, the letter had appeared on ''[[Russia Today]]'' and other Russian websites.<ref name="DFRL"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Общественность Донбасса обратилась к украинцам с требованием остановить войну на востоке страны|url=https://russian.rt.com/article/48117|work=RT|date=2 September 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6layN00y2|archivedate=2016-10-28|language=ru-RU|dead-url=no}}</ref>
One of the documents included in the leak was a 22-page outline of "a plan to support nationalist and separatist politicians and to encourage early parliamentary elections in Ukraine, all with the aim of undermining the government in [[Kiev]]."<ref name="FP">{{cite news|last1=Standish|first1=Reid|title=Hacked: Putin Aide’s Emails Detail Alleged Plot to Destabilize Ukraine|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/25/hacked-putin-aides-emails-detail-alleged-plot-to-destabilize-kiev-surkov-ukraine-leaks/|work=Foreign Policy|date=25 October 2016}}</ref>

{{italic title}} [[File:David Teniers the Younger - modello for Theatrum Pictorium 1673.jpg|thumb|Modello for the frontispiece for the ''Theatrum Pictorium'', by Teniers]] '''''Theatrum Pictorium''''', or ''Theatre of Painting'', is a short-hand name of a book published in the 1660s by [[David Teniers the Younger]] for his employer, the [[Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria]]. It was a catalog of 243 Italian paintings in the Archduke's collection of over 1300 paintings, with engravings of the paintings taken from small models that Teniers had personally prepared. A second edition with page numbers was published in 1673.
During the years 1646-1656 Leopold Wilhelm was governor of the Netherlands and formed one of the greatest art collections of his age. Teniers effectively became its curator after the death of his predecessor [[Jan van den Hoecke]] in 1651. Leopold Wilhelm’s collection came to hold works by [[Hans Holbein the Elder]], [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]], [[Jan van Eyck]], [[Raphael]], [[Giorgione]], [[Paolo Veronese]] and more than 15 works by [[Titian]]. Teniers made a list of the painters in the collection as part of the forward to his 1673 catalog: <gallery> File:Theatrum Pictorium gri 33125009347911 0012.jpg File:Theatrum Pictorium gri 33125009347911 0013.jpg </gallery>
This list is an important document that reflects the contemporary taste in paintings in Brussels at that time. Of all the painters, the names [[Magdalena Woutiers]] and [[Madonna Fitta de Milano]] are the only women whose work is documented as being in the Archduke's collection. No matter how illustrious the name however, only works by the better known Italian painters were chosen to be engraved for illustrations. At the end of his governorship, the Archduke and his collection moved to the [[Stallburg]]. This archducal collection now forms the heart of Vienna’s [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]].
Before moving to Vienna in 1659, Archduke Leopold Wilhelm formed his art collection in [[Brussels]], where [[David Teniers the Younger]] painted views of the most prized possessions of his Brussels gallery. He painted several of these in various compositions which are now spread among various collections:<ref>[https://www.khm.at/en/visit/collections/picture-gallery/history-of-the-collection/ History of the collections] of the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]]</ref> <gallery mode=packed> File:David Il G Teniers The Gallery of Archduke Leopold in Brussels 1.jpg| [[Staatsgalerie im Neuen Schloss|Staatsgalerie im Neuen Schloss, Schleißheim]], 1639 File:David Teniers (II) - The Gallery of Archduke Leopold in Brussels - WGA22066.jpg|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Schleissheim)]]'', [[Schleissheim Palace|Staatsgalerie im Neuen Schloss, Schleißheim]], 1640 File:David Teniers - Gallery of the Archduke Leopold Willem in Brussels KMSKB.jpg|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm (Brussels)]]'', [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], 1651 File:El archiduque Leopoldo Guillermo en su galería de pinturas en Bruselas (David Teniers II).jpg|''[[The Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in his Painting Gallery in Brussels]]'', [[Museo del Prado|Prado]] File:David Teniers d. J. 008.jpg|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Vienna)]]'', [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] File:Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels - Petworth House.jpg|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Petworth)]]'', [[Petworth House]] File:David teniers-lazaro galdiano.JPG|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Galdiano)]]'', [[Museo Lázaro Galdiano]] File:David Teniers II - Archduke Leopold Wilhelm and the artist in the archducal picture gallery in Brussels (1653).jpg|''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Rothschild)]]'', Private collection File:Nikolaus van Hoy - Theatrum Pictorium, View into the picture gallery of the Archduke Leopold in Brussels.jpg|View into the picture gallery of the Archduke Leopold, by [[Nikolaus van Hoy]] in Teniers' catalog of paintings in 1673<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/gri_33125009347911#page/n479/mode/1up Davidis Teniers Antverpiensis, pictoris, et a cubiculis ser.mis principibus Leopoldo Guil. archiduci et Ioanni Austriaco, Theatrum pictorium : in quo exhibentur ipsius manu delineatae, eiusque curâ in aes incisae picturae, archetipae italicae, quas ipse ser.mus archidux in pinacothecam suam Bruxellis collegit], by Teniers in 1673 on archive.org</ref> </gallery>
Teniers employed a team of 12 engravers for reproducing the 243 paintings in the Theatrum. He produced small copies in oil of each of the chosen paintings, issuing these as models to his engravers and 120 of which were auctioned by the estate of [[John Spencer-Churchill, 7th Duke of Marlborough]] in 1886.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=7BU-36sK16MC&pg=PA130 Fifteenth- to Eighteenth-century European Paintings in the Robert Lehman Collection: France, Central Europe, The Netherlands, Spain and Great Britain], by [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], Charles Sterling</ref> Teniers’ painted copies measuring approximately 17 x 25 cm are now spread among various collections. The [[Courtauld Institute of Art]] Gallery holds 14 of these works, the largest group in any public collection.<ref>[http://www.codart.com/exhibitions/details/1139/ David Teniers and the Theatre of Painting, 19 October 2006 – 21 January 2007] exhibition press release on [[codart]]</ref> Of the 12 engravers, the five who contributed most were [[Jan van Troyen]] with 56, [[Lucas Vorsterman the Younger]] with 52, [[Pieter van Lisebetten]] 40, [[Theodoor van Kessel]] 27, and [[Coryn Boel|Coryn]] or Quirin Boel 25.<ref>[http://www.hnanews.org/archive/2007/04/vegelin.html History of the project] on website for ''Historians of Netherlandish Art''</ref> [[Johannes Popels]] contributed five engravings.
==Surviving works== The works listed in the book that survive are generally in the Kunsthistorisches Museum, while the modelli or small models for the engravings have been lost or are in other collections. The engravings and the modelli were inscribed with the dimensions of the original paintings, though their characteristics were often adjusted to take advantage of the maximum illustration possibilities of the album page size. The dimensions were in the form "4 alta 3 lata", which means 4 palm-widths high and 3 palm-widths wide, such as the case with the engraving after [[Francesco Bassano the Younger|Bassano's]] ''Boy with a Flute'': <gallery> File:Francesco Bassano - Boy with Flute GG 8.jpg|Example of a painting by Francesco Bassano the Younger in the Kunsthistorisches Museum File:Teniers - Boy with a Flute GG 9708.jpg|Example of a modello by David Teniers the Younger after Bassano, also in the Kunsthistorisches Museum File:Arolsen Klebeband 13 035.jpg|Example of an engraving from the first, 1660, edition of the ''Theatrum Pictorium'' by Jan van Troyen after the Bassano painting </gallery>

revision.comment: /* Doctor's potential liability */Deleted full stops in abbreviation to match usage above
revision.text:
{{For|the basketball coach|2017 NCAA Division I men's basketball corruption scandal}} '''Anthony David Bland''' (21 September 1970 – 3 March 1993) was a supporter of [[Liverpool F.C.]] injured in the [[Hillsborough disaster]]. He suffered severe brain damage that left him in a [[persistent vegetative state]] as a consequence of which the hospital, with the support of his parents, applied for a court order allowing him to 'die with dignity'. As a result, he became the first patient in [[England|English]] legal history to be allowed to die by the courts through the withdrawal of life-prolonging treatment including food and water.
==The Hillsborough disaster== {{Main|Hillsborough disaster}} Bland was an 18-year-old Liverpool supporter who travelled with two friends to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]'s [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]] football ground for an [[FA Cup]] semi-final between [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 15 April 1989. During the game, a crush behind the Liverpool goal ensued due to the police losing control of the situation outside the ground. A crush had formed at the outer gates, and the Liverpool fans were eventually let in through a side gate by order of Chief Superintendent Duckenfield. However, he failed to close the tunnel access first and thousands more Liverpool fans were sent down this tunnel into pens 3 and 4 which were already overcrowded due to the failure of police officers and club stewards to direct the fans to the appropriate areas. This resulted in the death of 94 people on that day, and a 95th victim in hospital a few days later.
Although Bland survived the initial crush, he had suffered severe brain damage and eventually became the disaster's 96th victim on 3 March 1993, aged 22, after being in a coma for nearly four years. He never regained consciousness and a legal ruling in November 1992 allowed doctors to withdraw his treatment at the request of his family, as there had been no sign of improvement in his condition and the doctors treating him advised that there was no reasonable possibility that he would ever emerge from his persistent vegetative state, and was unlikely to survive more than five years.
== Injuries and prognosis==
Bland suffered serious injuries in the crush at the Leppings Lane terrace. He suffered crushed ribs and two punctured lungs, causing an interruption in the supply of oxygen to his brain. As a result, he sustained catastrophic and irreversible damage to the higher centres of the brain, which had left him in a [[persistent vegetative state]] (PVS).
He was transferred to the care of J. G. Howe, a consultant geriatrician and neurologist at the [[Airedale General Hospital]] near his home in [[Keighley]]. He had some experience in treating those with PVS. Several attempts were made by Howe and his team, along with Bland's father, sister and mother, to try to elicit some response from him and for some signs of interaction. However, all attempts failed. He showed no sign of being aware of anything that took place around him.
[[EEG]] and [[CT scan]]s revealed that whilst the [[brain stem]] remained intact, there was no cortical activity. Indeed, scans subsequently shown to the court showed more space than substance in the relevant part of his brain. His body was being kept alive by artificial nutrition, hydration and constant care. But the medical profession treating him stated that there was no reasonable possibility that he would ever emerge from his vegetative state.
==The law in England and Wales prior to Bland== ===Selective non-treatment of newborn babies=== Prior to Bland, English case law on the non-treatment of patients was restricted to newborn babies. There have been several recorded cases of disabled neonates being 'allowed to die'. A leading case was that of ''[[Re B (a minor)]]''.<ref>''Re B (a minor)'' [1990] 3 All ER 927</ref> That case involved a baby with [[Down syndrome]] complicated by [[intestinal obstruction]] which, if left untreated without surgery, would be fatal. The parents felt that it would be in the child's best interests if she were left to die. This was a decision upheld by Lord Justice Dunn at first instance, who lauded the parents' decision as being 'an entirely reasonable one'.
The matter reached the [[Court of Appeal]] who overturned the decision. Any such decision had to be made in the best interests of the child and that the prognosis was that the child would have a reasonable quality of life. However, in other cases, for example ''Re C (a minor) (wardship: medical treatment)'' <ref>''Re C (a minor) (wardship: medical treatment)'' [1989] 2 All ER 782</ref> and ''Re J (a minor) (wardship: medical treatment)'',<ref>''Re J (a minor) (wardship: medical treatment)'' [1990] 3 All ER 930</ref> this test has been used to determine that doctors can choose not to treat or provide life prolonging treatment.
===Doctor's potential liability=== In ''R v Arthur''<ref>''R v Arthur'' (1981) 12 BMLR 1</ref> a baby was born with uncomplicated Down Syndrome and was rejected by the parents. [[Leonard Arthur]], a [[Pediatrics|paediatrician]], wrote in his notes that the 'Parents do not wish it to survive. Nursing care only.' The baby died 69 hours later. During the trial, the defence provided evidence that the child was not physically healthy, resulting in a reduced charge of attempted murder, for which Arthur was acquitted.
This demonstrated that a doctor who deliberately withdrew life-prolonging treatment under any circumstances, and where the patient subsequently died, could be charged with murder. There was a subtle exception. If a patient suffered complications but the doctors felt that it would serve no purpose to apply additional treatments, such as antibiotics to fight infection, as might happen in a case of PVS and the patient subsequently died as a result of the complication then they were not liable under the criminal law. Theoretically, however, they could still find themselves being sued for negligence by the family of the deceased.
In August 1989, four months after Bland was injured, Howe contacted Popper, the Sheffield coroner, who was both legally and medically qualified. He informed Popper of the plan to withdraw all treatment including food and water. This decision had been taken following full consultation with the family and in accordance with their wishes. Howe later said:
{{cquote|It is difficult now [in 2006] to convey my shock on receiving his intimidating reply. Having stated that he [the Coroner] had no jurisdiction over any living person, he advised that I would risk a murder charge should I withdraw treatment. He made it clear that he "... could not countenance, condone, approve or give consent to any action or inaction which could be or could not be construed as being designed or intended to shorten or terminate the life of this young man. This particularly applies to the withholding of the necessities of life, such as food and drink." He requested a reply by return indicating that I had understood his opinion, and whether I would withdraw treatment.}}
The Coroner advised Howe to contact his medical defence society and the Regional Health Authority and copied his letter to the Chief Constable of the West Midlands Police (the investigating force), the local regional Health Authority solicitor and Howe's medical defence society. The following day Howe was visited by the police and told that he would be charged with murder if he withdrew treatment and Bland died.
Following the obtaining of the legal advice, which concurred with that of the coroner, the [[Airedale National Health Service Trust]], with the support of Bland's family and Howe, made an application to court to withdraw all life-prolonging treatment. As Bland was unable to speak for himself and was, for legal purposes, deemed an incompetent, the [[Official Solicitor]] was assigned as his [[guardian ad litem|guardian ''ad litem'']]. The Official Solicitor opposed the Trust's application because if the Trust were allowed to pursue the actions proposed by Howe, it would amount in law to the crime of [[murder in English law|murder]].
==The case== ===First instance=== Airedale NHS Trust applied to the courts for a declaration to the effect that: * they might lawfully discontinue all life-sustaining treatment and medical support measures, including ventilation, nutrition and hydration by artificial means * any subsequent treatment given should be for the sole purpose of enabling him to end his life in dignity and free from pain and suffering * if death should then occur, its cause should be attributed to the natural and other causes of his present state * and that none of those concerned should, as a result, be subject to any criminal or civil liability.
This declaration, apart from the latter part of the declaration{{clarify|which is the latter part?|date=November 2014}} (which was deemed inappropriate{{clarify|by whom, and why?|date=November 2014}}), was granted. The court considered that it was in the patient's best interests for treatment to be withheld and that its discontinuance was in accordance with good medical practice.
Acting on Anthony Bland's behalf, the Official Solicitor appealed this decision.
===The Court of Appeal=== ====Expert evidence==== Such was the importance of the case, and the obvious legal ramifications, it attracted a number of expert witnesses to give evidence. These included Professor [[Bryan Jennett]] who, along with Professor [[Fred Plum]], coined the term 'persistent vegetative state' in 1972. Professor Jennett expressed the view that it would be in accordance with good medical practice in the case of Anthony Bland to withdraw the nasogastric artificial feeding. He considered that there was no benefit to continue with the treatment as there was no prospect of recovery of cognitive function.
Other experts in the field of neurology gave evidence. Amongst those was Professor [[Peter O'Behan]] who examined Bland on behalf of the Official Solicitor. Like the experts who gave evidence for the Airedale Trust, Prof. O'Behan's evidence was pessimistic. He stated:
{{cquote|I am confident that from my knowledge of other patients, neuropsychology, previous cases from the literature and from animal experimentation that the patient has no awareness nor can he suffer pain or experience pleasure. Further the prospect of improvement can also confidently be answered since based on what we know of the degree of damage to his brain, the comparison of his case with those recorded in the literature (particularly considering the nature of his damage and the duration of his illness) and the type of systems and signs he exhibits, there is no hint or hope or any prospect of improvement.}}
==Inquest and failed legal challenge== On 21 December 1993, [[Bradford]] coroner James Turnbull recorded a verdict of accidental death on Tony Bland.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/hillsborough-victim-died-accidentally-coroner-says-withdrawal-of-treatment-not-to-blame-1469037.html|title=Hillsborough victim died 'accidentally': Coroner says withdrawal of|author=MALCOLM PITHERS, Northern Correspondent|date=22 December 1993|work=The Independent}}</ref> The same verdict was recorded on the other 95 victims (94 who died on the day of the disaster and a 95th who died a few days later) at the main Hillsborough inquest in March 1991, much to the dismay of the bereaved families who had been hoping for a verdict of unlawful killing and for manslaughter charges to be brought against the police who had been patrolling the match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/28/newsid_2531000/2531015.stm|title=BBC ON THIS DAY - 28 - 1991: Family anger at Hillsborough verdict|publisher=}}</ref> On 26 April 2016, during the second inquest on all 96 victims, a verdict of Unlawful Killing was issued on all 96 victims. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/hillsborough-disaster-verdict-unlawful-killing-david-duckenfield-ruling-by-inquests-jury-over-1989-a7001276.html|title=Hillsborough disaster verdict: Inquest jury delivers 'unlawful killing' ruling over 1989 football deaths|author=Ian Herbert|date=26 April 2016|work=The Independent}}</ref>
In the aftermath of Bland's death, a priest and anti-abortion campaigner, Fr James Morrow, started a legal challenge to have the doctor who withdrew his treatment charged with murder, but this was rejected by the [[High Court of England and Wales|High Court]] in April 1994.
On 28 June 2017, the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] announced that David Duckenfield, the police commander, would be charged with manslaughter by gross negligence in relation to the deaths of the other 95 victims, but a charge could not apply in relation to Bland because he died outside of the time limit that was applicable for the time of the alleged offence.<ref>http://cps.gov.uk/news/latest_news/hillsborough-charging-decisions/</ref>
==Moral and legal issues== The case brought up a number of moral and legal issues. As a result, the number of previous cases referred to is extensive.
This case is another which delegated to the ''Bolam'' standard. This was a test introduced by the courts in ''[[Bolam v. Friern Hospital Management Committee]]''. The essence of the ''Bolam'' standard is such as to remove liability from medical staff if the treatment they have provided to a patient under the particular circumstances would have been followed by a responsible body of medical personnel, exercising due skill and care in the process. Under Bolam, a doctor need only show that he was following an accepted medical practice - even if that practice was only followed by a minority of medical professionals. This was one of the arguments put forward on behalf of Dr. Howe; that it would be intolerable if Dr. Howe was charged with murder for following what he submitted to be generally regarded as good medical practice.
A long-time critic of the ''Bland'' case, Dr [[Jacqueline Laing]] argues that the implications of the judicial decision deserve revisiting given recent Freedom of Information Act requests revealing financial incentives and staggering compliance{{clarify|what is that supposed to mean?|date=November 2014}}<ref>Laing, J 2012 'A Lethal Power?' New Law Journal, 162, 1444</ref> in rolling out the 2008 NHS End-Of-Life Care strategy. She warns that Bland has been dangerously extended by the Mental Capacity Act 2005 so that novel third parties now have power to remove treatment.<ref>Laing, J 2004 'Mental Capacity Bill - A threat to the vulnerable' New Law Journal 154, 1165. Laing, J 2005 'The Mental Capacity Bill 2004: Human Rights Concerns' Family Law Journal 35, 137-143. Laing, J 2008 'Food and Fluids: Human Law, Human Rights and Human Interests' in Artificial Nutrition and Hydration C. Tollefsen, ed., Springer Press, pp. 77-100 </ref>
==Andrew Devine== Tony Bland was one of two people injured at Hillsborough to have been diagnosed as being in a persistent vegetative state. The other was 22-year-old Andrew Devine, also from the Liverpool area, who also suffered massive brain damage as a result of being deprived of oxygen due to crush injuries and in the immediate aftermath of the disaster his parents were warned by doctors that he was likely to die within a few months. In 1994, five years after the disaster and one year after the death of Tony Bland, Devine's family claimed to have seen him following a moving object with his eyes. By March 1997, Devine was able to communicate to others using a touch-sensitive buzzer to answer "yes" or "no" to questions asked.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/flicker-of-hope-from-brain-damage-victim-astonishes-doctors-1275217.html|title=Flicker of hope from brain damage victim astonishes doctors|author=Annabel Ferriman|date=27 March 1997|work=The Independent}}</ref> By the time of the disaster's 20th anniversary in April 2009, it was reported that he continues to show signs of awareness around him but his condition has barely improved since he was first reported to have emerged from the coma 12 years earlier.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2009/04/11/hillsborough-remembered-moving-devotion-of-a-mum-and-dad-whose-son-has-been-comatose-for-20-years-115875-21272202/|title=Hillsborough remembered: Moving devotion of a mum and dad whose son has been comatose for 20 years|author=Kate Mansey|date=11 April 2009|work=mirror}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}} * [http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/1992/5.html] Airedale NHS Trust v Bland [1993] 1 All ER 821 HL * Finnis J M 1993 'Bland: Crossing the Rubicon', ''Law Quarterly Review'' 109: pp329–337 * Harris, J 2003 ''The Value of Life'', London; Routledge * Howe, J 2006 'The persistent vegetative state, treatment withdrawal, and the Hillsborough disaster: Airedale NHS Trust v Bland', ''Practical Neurology'', 2006:6(4) pp238-246 * Jennett, B 2002 The Vegetative State, Cambridge; Cambridge University Press * Kelly, K 1993 'Comment on the Bland case', 13 March * Laing, J 2002 'Vegetative” State – The Untold Story' ''New Law Journal'' 152, 1272. * Laing, J 2004 'Mental Capacity Bill - A threat to the vulnerable' ''New Law Journal'' 154, 1165. * Laing, J 2005 'The Mental Capacity Bill 2004: Human Rights Concerns' ''Family Law Journal'' 35, 137-143. * Laing, J 2008 'Food and Fluids: Human Law, Human Rights and Human Interests' in ''Artificial Nutrition and Hydration'' C. Tollefsen, ed., Springer Press, pp. 77-100 * Laing, J 2012 'A Lethal Power?' ''New Law Journal'', 162, 1444 * Laing, J 2013 'Incentivising Death' ''Solicitors Journal'', 157, 9 * McLean, S 1999 'Legal and ethical aspects of the vegetative state', ''Journal of Clinical Pathology'', Vol 52, pp490–493 * Royal College of Physicians 1996 'Report on the permanent vegetative state', ''Journal of RCP'' 30, pp 119–121 * Scraton P 2000 ''Hillsborough: The Truth'', Edinburgh; Mainstream Publications * Scraton P, Jemphrey, A and Coleman S 1995 ''No Last Rights: The Denial of Justice and the Promotion of Myth in the Aftermath of the Hillsborough Disaster'', Liverpool; Alden Press/LCC
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311201106/http://www.catholicdoctors.org.uk/CMQ/Feb_1995/neuropath_tony_bland.htm Neuropathological findings in cases of Persistent Vegetative State, Catholic Quarterly, February 1995] *[http://www.bioethics.ac.uk/publications/vegetative-state.pdf Persistent Vegetative State: An introduction to duty of care issues, with reference to a UK case]
{{EthicsCases}}

revision.text:
{{notability|Events|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox recurring event |name = Youth of the Nation Conference |logo =[[Image:Youth_of_the_Nation_Logo_2018.jpg|frameless]] |image = |caption = |location = [[Wanganui]], New Zealand |years_active = 2004–2018 |dates = |genre = [[Christian]] |website = http://www.yotn.net.nz/ }} '''Youth of the Nation''' was an annual [[Christian]] Youth Conference held for 15 years in [[Wanganui]], New Zealand. Unlike many other Christian conferences, YOTN was not held by one specific church or denomination. Youth of the Nation conferences and events were hosted by The Youth Of The Nation Trust in collaboration with other churches from around New Zealand. For the first 8 years the conferences were hosted by the [[Wanganui Christian Youth Workers]]The official Youth of the Nation Website {{cite web|url=http://www.yotn.net.nz/mainindex.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014011528/http://www.yotn.net.nz/mainindex.html |archivedate=October 14, 2008 }} collective, a group of Christian youth pastors & workers from different denominations & churches across the city of Wanganui. This collective included representatives from [[Anglican]], [[Apostolic Church (denomination)|Apostolic]], [[Assemblies of God]], [[Baptist]], [[Open Brethren]], [[Catholic]], Incedo, [[Presbyterian]], Christian Outreach Centre—now known as International Network of Churches—, [[Elim Pentecostal Church|Elim]], [[Salvation Army]], & non-denominational. From 2012 until 2018, the YOTN Trust partnered with churches, not only in Wanganui, but from across New Zealand to host events in different cities. == Introduction == Youth of the Nation (YOTN) aimed to encourage and empower Christian young people to pursue [[Jesus Christ]] with a zeal that will impact their generation. As an event, the goal was to provide a 3-4 day event that was affordable for more New Zealand young people, while maintaining the standards & excellence of some of the leading national conferences. The vision to hold YOTN came from Wanganui [[Assemblies of God|A/G]] youth pastor, [[Ben Hoyle]]. In 2003, Ben approached the local city youth workers to hold the conference as a city. He recognised that for one church to put on such a large event was too much, and that together the city could pull its resources and achieve the goal. With many of the city youth workers on board, plans were made to hold the very first conference in July 2004. Each year YOTN gained momentum seeing attendance grow and more young people leave excited about their faith.
"YOTN continues to build in its momentum, magnitude and excellence. It is great to see more and more young people coming and leaving radically changed. The greatest thrill for me is seeing the hunger in the younger generation for the reality of God and a deep desire to walk in God's ways. Long may it continue." - ''[[Illiafi Esera|Ps Iliafi Esera]] (Faith City Church A/G, [[Wanganui]])''quoted from "Youth of The Nation IV Report" Empowered Magazine Spring 2007 Edition Page 10
In 2011, the event moved from the Wanganui Central Baptist Church, where it had been held for 6 years, to the School Hall at Wanganui City College. Then in 2012, YOTN IX was moved to the War Memorial Hall Convention Centre which seats 1500 people, where the conference was held until 2015.The ''[[Wanganui Chronicle]]'' Monday 16 July 2012 Page A4 Ben Hoyle resigned as YOTN director in 2018 and Youth of the Nation Trust & events were absorbed into the Fearless Movement of the Assemblies of God NZ under the leadership of Ps Mike Coe from [[Timaru]]. YOTN held it's final conference in April 2018 at Whanganui Central Bpatist Church. The theme for 2018 was 'Possible' and involved reflecting on the past 15 years. Ps Ben Hoyle spoke the final message of conference and Ps Mike Coe closed the conference by announcing the future with Fearless.''Empowered Magazine'' Edition #2 August 2018 Page 18-19 == History == ===Conferences=== Starting with Youth of the Nation 2004, the conference has been held annually.The official Youth of the Nation Website: History Page {{cite web|url=http://www.yotn.net.nz/history.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=August 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014012056/http://www.yotn.net.nz/history.html |archivedate=October 14, 2008 }} The first decade of YOTN Conferences were headlined by guest speakers and guest artists. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Dates ! Venue ! Featured Speakers ! Featured Artists |- | 2004 | Youth of the Nation 2004 | 2–4 July | Faith Community Church | Ps Graeme Brock (The Tribe, [[Masterton]] NZ)
Timo Tagaloa ([[Athletes in Action]], [[Auckland]] NZ)
Ps Tim King (Advance Ministry Training College, [[Auckland]] NZ) | Wash ([[Auckland]] NZ)
[[Rapture Ruckus]] ([[Wellington]] NZ)
Colliding Traits ([[Auckland]] NZ) |- | 2005 | Youth of the Nation 05 | 8–10 July | Central Baptist Church | Ps John Cairns (Power & Light Ministries, [[Melbourne]] AUS)
Ps Paul Saunders (Global Task, [[Auckland]] NZ)
[[Justin Duckworth]] (Global Education Centre, [[Wellington]] NZ) | [[Moped (band)|Moped]] ([[Wellington]] NZ)
Agent'c ([[Wellington]] NZ)
Assorted Sweets ([[Wellington]] NZ) |- | 2006 | Youth of the Nation III | 30 June -

YOTN Possible |} == Youth of the Nation: Preliminary event == YOTN held a special preliminary event, held in Term One of the [[Academic term|school year]]. Ps Kem Price (Kem Price Ministries, [[Auckland]]) | |} == YOTN Championship == In 2008, the conference added a [[sports]] extension. The YOTN [[Championship]] is a sports tournament where different churches/youth groups attending the conference entered teams to compete for the YOTN [[Championship]] [[Trophy]]. It is a fun competitive event. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Conference ! Venue ! Winners !
